canonical_explanation.text: Adolescence is the period of life between the ages of about 11 and 18-19 years, during which the body undergoes significant changes leading to reproductive maturity. The onset of puberty marks the beginning of adolescence. During puberty, the body experiences several changes: increase in height, changes in body shape, voice changes (especially in boys), development of reproductive organs, and the appearance of secondary sexual characters. These changes are controlled by hormones — chemical substances secreted by endocrine glands. The pituitary gland (master gland) signals the testes to produce testosterone in boys and the ovaries to produce estrogen in girls. Other endocrine glands include the thyroid (controls metabolism), adrenal glands (produce adrenaline for emergencies), and pancreas (produces insulin for blood sugar regulation). Sex of a baby is determined by the sex chromosomes: XX for female and XY for male. Maintaining good health during adolescence requires a balanced diet, personal hygiene, regular physical exercise, and saying no to drugs.
rules: Adolescence is the period from about 11 to 18-19 years of age.
Puberty is the age at which the reproductive organs become functional and secondary sexual characters develop.
Changes at puberty: increase in height, change in body shape, voice changes, development of sex organs, appearance of body hair.
Secondary sexual characters in boys: facial hair, deeper voice, broad shoulders.
Secondary sexual characters in girls: development of breasts, widening of hips, higher-pitched voice.
Testosterone is the male hormone produced by testes; estrogen is the female hormone produced by ovaries.
The pituitary gland is the 'master gland' that controls other endocrine glands.
Endocrine glands secrete hormones directly into the blood (ductless glands).
Thyroid gland produces thyroxine (requires iodine); controls growth and metabolism.
Pancreas produces insulin; regulates blood sugar level.
Sex determination: XX chromosomes = female; XY chromosomes = male (father determines sex).
Adolescents need a balanced diet, physical exercise, personal hygiene, and must avoid drugs.

questions.question_text: Adolescence is the period of life between ages:
questions.explanation_correct: Adolescence is the period of life that begins around age 11 and lasts till 18 or 19. It is the transition period between childhood and adulthood during which the body undergoes significant changes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ages 1-5 is early childhood, 5-10 is middle childhood, and 25-40 is adulthood. Adolescence specifically covers the teenage years from about 11 to 18-19 when puberty and growth occur.

questions.question_text: The onset of puberty brings about changes in the body. Puberty is:

options.text: The age at which the body becomes capable of reproduction
The time when growth stops completely

questions.explanation_correct: Puberty is the period when the human body undergoes changes that make it capable of reproduction. The reproductive organs become functional, and secondary sexual characters begin to develop.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Puberty is not related to old age, infancy, or growth stopping. It specifically marks the beginning of sexual maturation, when the body develops the ability to reproduce.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a change that occurs during puberty?

options.text: Increase in height and development of secondary sexual characters

questions.explanation_correct: During puberty, there is a noticeable increase in height (growth spurt) and development of secondary sexual characters like body hair, voice changes, and changes in body shape.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Puberty involves growth (increase in height), not decrease. Body hair grows rather than being lost. Changes include weight gain along with height increase and the development of secondary sexual characters.

questions.question_text: The voice of boys becomes deeper during puberty because of:

options.text: Growth of hair on the face

questions.explanation_correct: During puberty in boys, the voice box (larynx) grows larger and produces a deeper voice. The growing voice box can sometimes be seen as a protruding Adam's apple in the throat.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Facial hair, height increase, and skin changes are separate pubertal changes. The voice change is specifically caused by the enlargement of the larynx, which causes the vocal cords to become longer and thicker.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a secondary sexual character in boys?

options.text: Growth of facial hair (moustache and beard)

questions.explanation_correct: Growth of facial hair (moustache and beard) is a secondary sexual character in boys. Other male secondary characters include a deeper voice, broad shoulders, and growth of chest hair.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Development of breasts and widening of hips are female secondary characters. A higher-pitched voice is characteristic of girls. Facial hair growth is a distinctly male secondary sexual character.

questions.question_text: During adolescence, the increase in height is most rapid because:

options.text: The long bones of arms and legs elongate and the body reaches its maximum height

questions.explanation_correct: During the growth spurt of adolescence, the long bones of the legs and arms elongate significantly due to the action of growth hormones. This leads to a rapid increase in height until the person reaches their maximum height.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bones actively grow (not stop) during adolescence. Both bones and muscles grow. The body does not lose calcium. The elongation of long bones, stimulated by growth hormones, is responsible for the height increase.

questions.question_text: The protruding part in the throat of adolescent boys is called Adam's apple. It is caused by:
questions.explanation_correct: Adam's apple is the visible protrusion in the throat caused by the enlargement of the larynx (voice box) during puberty in boys. It grows larger in boys than in girls, making it more noticeable.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Adam's apple is not a new bone, a swelling, or a disease. It is the outward appearance of the enlarged larynx, which grows during puberty and causes the voice to become deeper.

questions.question_text: Chemical substances secreted by endocrine glands that control body functions are called:
questions.explanation_correct: Hormones are chemical substances produced by endocrine glands and released directly into the bloodstream. They act as chemical messengers, controlling various body functions like growth, metabolism, and reproduction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Enzymes speed up chemical reactions. Vitamins are nutrients from food. Antibodies fight infections. Hormones are the specific chemical messengers produced by endocrine glands.

questions.question_text: Which gland is called the 'master gland' because it controls other endocrine glands?
questions.explanation_correct: The pituitary gland is called the 'master gland' because it produces hormones that control the functioning of other endocrine glands such as the thyroid, adrenals, and reproductive glands.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The thyroid controls metabolism, adrenals handle stress responses, and the pancreas regulates blood sugar. The pituitary gland is specifically called the master gland because it directs other endocrine glands.

questions.question_text: The male hormone produced by the testes is:
questions.explanation_correct: Testosterone is the male hormone produced by the testes. It is responsible for the development of male secondary sexual characters such as facial hair, deeper voice, and muscular development during puberty.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Estrogen is the female hormone. Insulin regulates blood sugar. Thyroxine controls metabolism. Testosterone is the specific male hormone produced by the testes.

questions.question_text: The female hormone produced by the ovaries is:
questions.explanation_correct: Estrogen is the female hormone produced by the ovaries. It is responsible for the development of female secondary sexual characters such as breast development, widening of hips, and regulation of the menstrual cycle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Testosterone is the male hormone. Adrenaline is produced by adrenal glands for stress response. Thyroxine is produced by the thyroid. Estrogen is the key female reproductive hormone.

questions.question_text: The thyroid gland produces thyroxine, which requires which element for its synthesis?
questions.explanation_correct: Iodine is essential for the synthesis of thyroxine by the thyroid gland. A deficiency of iodine in the diet can cause the thyroid to swell, a condition known as goitre.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Calcium is for bones, iron for haemoglobin, and sodium for nerve function. Iodine is specifically required by the thyroid gland to produce the hormone thyroxine.

questions.question_text: A person has a swollen neck (goitre). This is most likely caused by:

options.text: Excess of iron in the diet
Deficiency of iodine in the diet
Excess of calcium in the diet

questions.explanation_correct: Goitre is caused by a deficiency of iodine in the diet. Without sufficient iodine, the thyroid gland cannot produce enough thyroxine and swells in an attempt to compensate, forming a visible lump in the neck.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Goitre is not caused by iron, calcium excess, or vitamin C deficiency. It is specifically linked to iodine deficiency. This is why iodised salt is recommended to prevent goitre.

questions.question_text: Insulin is a hormone produced by the pancreas. Its main function is to:
questions.explanation_correct: Insulin is produced by the pancreas and its main function is to regulate blood sugar (glucose) levels. It helps cells absorb glucose from the blood, lowering blood sugar levels after eating.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Growth is controlled by growth hormone from the pituitary. Digestive enzymes are different from hormones. Stress response is controlled by adrenaline. Insulin specifically regulates blood sugar.

questions.question_text: The adrenal glands produce adrenaline, which is released during:
questions.explanation_correct: Adrenaline (also called the 'fight or flight' hormone) is released by the adrenal glands during stressful, dangerous, or exciting situations. It increases heart rate, blood pressure, and energy levels to prepare the body for action.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Adrenaline is not released during sleep, digestion, or relaxation. It is the body's emergency hormone, released when we feel threatened, scared, or excited, preparing us for a quick response.

questions.question_text: Endocrine glands are different from other glands because they:

options.text: Have ducts to carry their secretions
Are ductless and secrete hormones directly into the blood
Are found only in the brain

questions.explanation_correct: Endocrine glands are ductless glands that secrete hormones directly into the bloodstream. This is unlike exocrine glands (like sweat glands or salivary glands) that have ducts to carry their secretions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Endocrine glands do NOT have ducts; they are ductless. They produce hormones (not enzymes), and are found in various parts of the body (not only the brain). Their unique feature is secreting directly into the blood.

questions.question_text: The sex of a baby is determined by:

options.text: The father's chromosomes (whether sperm carries X or Y)

questions.explanation_correct: The sex of a baby depends on whether the sperm from the father carries an X or Y chromosome. If an X-carrying sperm fertilises the egg, the baby will be female (XX). If a Y-carrying sperm fertilises the egg, the baby will be male (XY).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The mother always contributes an X chromosome. The father's sperm determines the sex by contributing either an X (girl) or Y (boy) chromosome. Diet and time of birth have no effect on sex determination.

questions.question_text: A baby will be female if the sex chromosome combination is:
questions.explanation_correct: A female baby has the sex chromosome combination XX. One X comes from the mother and one X from the father. Males have XY — the X from the mother and Y from the father.
questions.explanation_incorrect: XY results in a male. YY is not a possible combination. XO is an abnormal condition. XX is the normal sex chromosome combination for females.

questions.question_text: For a healthy adolescence, which of the following is most important?

options.text: A balanced diet, personal hygiene, and regular physical exercise

questions.explanation_correct: A balanced diet (with proteins, carbohydrates, fats, vitamins, and minerals), personal hygiene, and regular physical exercise are essential for healthy adolescent development. These provide nutrients for growth and keep the body fit.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fast food, skipping meals, and avoiding exercise are all harmful during adolescence. The body needs proper nutrition and activity during this critical growth period.

questions.question_text: Why is it said that the father is responsible for the sex of the baby?

options.text: Because the father is always present at birth
Because the mother always contributes X, while the father contributes either X or Y chromosome
Because the mother has no role in sex determination

questions.explanation_correct: The mother always provides an X chromosome (since her sex chromosomes are XX). The father can provide either an X or a Y chromosome (since his sex chromosomes are XY). So it is the father's sperm that determines whether the baby will be XX (female) or XY (male).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The father's age or presence at birth is irrelevant. The mother does have a role (contributing X), but since she always contributes X, it is the father's sperm (X or Y) that determines the sex of the baby.

questions.question_text: During puberty, girls experience widening of the region below the waist. This is a:
questions.explanation_correct: Widening of the hip region in girls is a secondary sexual character that develops during puberty under the influence of the hormone estrogen. It is not related to illness or diet but is a natural developmental change.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Primary sexual characters are the reproductive organs present from birth. Secondary sexual characters develop during puberty. Widening of hips in girls is a normal secondary sexual character, not a disease or dietary effect.

questions.question_text:
Match the endocrine gland with its hormone:
(a) Pituitary — (i) Insulin
(b) Thyroid — (ii) Growth hormone
(c) Pancreas — (iii) Thyroxine
Choose the correct match:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct matches are: Pituitary produces growth hormone (ii), Thyroid produces thyroxine (iii), and Pancreas produces insulin (i). Each gland has specific hormones with distinct functions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Pituitary secretes growth hormone (not insulin or thyroxine). Thyroid secretes thyroxine (not insulin or growth hormone). Pancreas secretes insulin (not growth hormone or thyroxine).

questions.question_text:
Assertion: Girls generally reach puberty earlier than boys.
Reason: Puberty in girls begins at about 10-11 years, while in boys it begins at about 12-13 years.
Choose the correct option:

options.text: Both assertion and reason are correct, and reason explains the assertion
Both are correct, but reason does not explain the assertion
Assertion is correct, but reason is incorrect

questions.explanation_correct: Both statements are correct, and the reason explains the assertion. Girls typically begin puberty around 10-11 years of age, which is about 1-2 years earlier than boys, who typically begin puberty around 12-13 years.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Girls do reach puberty earlier than boys on average. The reason correctly states the typical ages: about 10-11 for girls and 12-13 for boys, which directly explains why girls reach puberty first.

questions.question_text:
Which of the following statements about hormones is correct?
(i) Hormones are produced by endocrine glands.
(ii) Hormones are released directly into the blood.
(iii) Hormones act as chemical messengers.
(iv) Hormones are produced in large quantities.
questions.explanation_correct: Statements (i), (ii), and (iii) are correct. Hormones are produced by endocrine glands, released directly into the blood, and act as chemical messengers. Statement (iv) is incorrect — hormones are produced in very small quantities and are highly effective even in minute amounts.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Statement (iv) is incorrect. Hormones are produced in very small (trace) amounts, but they have powerful effects on the body. They are effective at very low concentrations in the blood.

questions.question_text: If a couple has only daughters, it is because:

options.text: Only X-chromosome-bearing sperms from the father fertilised the eggs
The daughters chose to be female
It is purely random and has no biological explanation

questions.explanation_correct: If a couple has only daughters, it means that in each case, a sperm carrying an X chromosome fertilised the ovum. Since the mother always contributes X, the combination XX (female) resulted each time. The father's X-bearing sperms happened to fertilise the eggs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The mother always provides X chromosomes and is not responsible for the sex of the baby. The sex is determined by whether an X or Y sperm from the father fertilises the egg. Having all daughters is a chance occurrence of X-bearing sperms being successful.

questions.question_text: A person has very high blood sugar levels. This could be due to a deficiency of:
questions.explanation_correct: Insulin is the hormone produced by the pancreas that lowers blood sugar levels. A deficiency of insulin leads to high blood sugar, a condition known as diabetes mellitus.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Thyroxine controls metabolism. Adrenaline handles stress responses. Growth hormone controls growth. Insulin is specifically responsible for regulating blood glucose, and its deficiency causes diabetes.

questions.question_text: Why is drug abuse particularly dangerous during adolescence?

options.text: Because the body and brain are still developing, making them more vulnerable to damage
Because adolescents have more free time
Because drugs are illegal only for adolescents

questions.explanation_correct: Drug abuse is particularly dangerous during adolescence because the body and brain are still developing. Drugs can interfere with normal growth, brain development, and the functioning of the endocrine system, causing lasting damage.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The danger of drug abuse for adolescents is not about cost, free time, or legality. It is because the adolescent body and brain are undergoing critical development, and drugs can cause serious, sometimes permanent, damage to this process.

questions.question_text: Which of the following changes occurs in both boys and girls during puberty?

options.text: Growth of hair in the underarm and pubic areas
Deepening of voice to a great extent

questions.explanation_correct: Growth of hair in the underarm and pubic areas is a change that occurs in both boys and girls during puberty. Facial hair is specific to boys, breast development to girls, and significant voice deepening mainly to boys.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Facial hair growth and major voice deepening are primarily male changes. Breast development is a female change. Growth of underarm and pubic hair is a common change that occurs in both sexes during puberty.

questions.question_text: Which hormone is responsible for the 'fight or flight' response in the body?
questions.explanation_correct: Adrenaline is responsible for the 'fight or flight' response. When released by the adrenal glands during stress or danger, it increases heart rate, blood flow to muscles, and alertness, preparing the body for immediate action.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Insulin regulates blood sugar. Thyroxine controls metabolism. Estrogen is a female reproductive hormone. Adrenaline is the emergency hormone that prepares the body to either fight the danger or flee from it.

questions.question_text: The total number of chromosomes in a human body cell is:
questions.explanation_correct: Human body cells contain 46 chromosomes arranged in 23 pairs. Of these, 22 pairs are autosomes (non-sex chromosomes) and 1 pair is the sex chromosomes (XX in females, XY in males).
questions.explanation_incorrect: 23 is the number in a gamete (haploid), not a body cell. 44 is the number of autosomes only. 48 is incorrect. The total number of chromosomes in a human body cell is 46 (23 pairs).

questions.question_text: Puberty in girls begins earlier than in boys.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is true. Girls generally reach puberty about 1-2 years earlier than boys. Puberty in girls typically starts around age 10-11, while in boys it starts around age 12-13.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Girls typically begin puberty earlier, around 10-11 years of age, while boys typically begin around 12-13 years. However, the exact age can vary from person to person.

questions.question_text: The pituitary gland is located in the stomach.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is false. The pituitary gland is located at the base of the brain, not in the stomach. It is a small, pea-sized gland that is often called the 'master gland' of the endocrine system.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is false. The pituitary gland is attached to the base of the brain (hypothalamus). The pancreas is the endocrine gland located near the stomach.

questions.question_text: The sex of a baby is determined by the sex chromosomes contributed by the father.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is true. The mother always contributes an X chromosome, while the father can contribute either an X or a Y. If the father's sperm carries X, the baby is female (XX); if it carries Y, the baby is male (XY).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Since the mother's egg always contains an X chromosome, it is the father's sperm (X or Y) that determines whether the offspring will be female (XX) or male (XY).

questions.question_text: Deficiency of iodine in the diet can cause goitre, a swelling of the thyroid gland.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is true. Iodine is essential for the thyroid gland to produce thyroxine. Without sufficient iodine, the thyroid gland enlarges, causing a visible swelling in the neck called goitre.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Goitre is directly linked to iodine deficiency. The thyroid gland swells because it is trying to produce thyroxine without adequate iodine. This is why iodised salt is recommended.

questions.question_text: Adolescents often experience mood swings and emotional changes, which are partly caused by hormonal changes.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is true. During adolescence, hormonal changes can cause mood swings, feelings of insecurity, and emotional changes. These are normal parts of growing up as the body adjusts to new hormone levels.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. The surge in hormones during puberty affects not only physical development but also emotions and mental state. Mood swings are a well-documented effect of hormonal changes during adolescence.

questions.question_text: Insulin deficiency in the body leads to a condition called diabetes.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is true. When the pancreas does not produce enough insulin, blood sugar levels rise uncontrollably, leading to diabetes mellitus. This condition requires medical management through insulin injections or medication.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. Diabetes mellitus occurs when the body cannot regulate blood sugar properly due to insufficient insulin production or insulin resistance. It is a serious condition affecting millions worldwide.

questions.question_text: A human body cell contains 23 pairs of chromosomes, out of which one pair is the sex chromosome pair.
questions.explanation_correct: This statement is true. Human body cells have 23 pairs (46 total) of chromosomes. Of these, 22 pairs are autosomes and 1 pair is the sex chromosomes (XX in females, XY in males).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is true. The 23 pairs consist of 22 pairs of autosomes and 1 pair of sex chromosomes. The sex chromosomes determine whether a person is male (XY) or female (XX).

questions.question_text: The period of life from about 11 to 18-19 years when the body undergoes changes leading to reproductive maturity is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Adolescence is the transitional period between childhood and adulthood, lasting from about 11 to 18-19 years. It is characterised by physical growth, hormonal changes, and emotional development.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'adolescence'. This period begins with puberty and continues until the body reaches full maturity. Adolescents are also called teenagers.

questions.question_text: The endocrine gland that controls other glands and is called the 'master gland' is the ___ gland.
questions.explanation_correct: The pituitary gland is called the master gland because it produces hormones that regulate the functioning of other endocrine glands in the body, including the thyroid, adrenal glands, and reproductive glands.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'pituitary'. Located at the base of the brain, this small but powerful gland secretes hormones that stimulate and control the activity of many other endocrine glands.

questions.question_text: The hormone ___ is produced by the testes and is responsible for male secondary sexual characters.
questions.explanation_correct: Testosterone is the male sex hormone produced by the testes. It triggers the development of secondary sexual characters like facial hair, deeper voice, and broader shoulders during puberty.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'testosterone'. This hormone is responsible for the changes that occur in boys during puberty, including muscle development, voice deepening, and facial hair growth.

questions.question_text: In humans, the sex chromosomes of a female are ___ and those of a male are XY.
questions.explanation_correct: Females have two X chromosomes (XX), while males have one X and one Y chromosome (XY). The mother always provides an X, and the father provides either X or Y.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'XX'. Human females have two X chromosomes, one from each parent. Males have one X (from mother) and one Y (from father).

questions.question_text: The thyroid gland requires ___ in the diet to produce the hormone thyroxine.
questions.explanation_correct: Iodine is an essential element needed by the thyroid gland to synthesise the hormone thyroxine. A deficiency of iodine leads to goitre (swelling of the thyroid gland).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'iodine'. This is why iodised salt (salt fortified with iodine) is recommended in the diet, especially in areas where natural iodine intake from food is insufficient.

questions.question_text: The hormone secreted by the pancreas that regulates blood sugar level is ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Insulin is produced by the pancreas and helps regulate blood glucose levels. It allows cells to absorb glucose from the blood, lowering blood sugar after meals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'insulin'. This hormone is crucial for blood sugar regulation. When insulin production is insufficient, blood sugar rises, leading to diabetes mellitus.

questions.question_text: The enlargement of the voice box during puberty in boys causes the voice to become deeper. The voice box is also called the ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The larynx (voice box) enlarges significantly in boys during puberty, causing the vocal cords to grow longer and thicker, which produces a deeper voice. The enlarged larynx is visible as Adam's apple.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'larynx'. The larynx is the organ in the throat that contains the vocal cords. Its growth during puberty causes the characteristic voice deepening in boys.

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly lists secondary sexual characters in girls?

options.text: Facial hair, deeper voice, broad shoulders
Breast development, widening of hips, higher-pitched voice
Adam's apple, muscular body, facial hair
Growth of beard, chest hair, increased muscle mass

questions.explanation_correct: Secondary sexual characters in girls include breast development, widening of hips, and maintenance of a higher-pitched voice. Options A, C, and D list male secondary sexual characters.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Facial hair, deeper voice, broad shoulders, Adam's apple, muscular body, beard, and chest hair are all male secondary sexual characters. Female characters include breast development, wider hips, and softer skin.

questions.question_text: A child's height is not increasing despite adequate nutrition. This could be due to deficiency of:

options.text: Growth hormone from the pituitary gland

questions.explanation_correct: Growth hormone is produced by the pituitary gland and is essential for proper growth and development. Its deficiency leads to stunted growth (dwarfism), even if nutrition is adequate.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Insulin controls blood sugar. Adrenaline handles stress. Testosterone affects male characteristics. Growth hormone from the pituitary gland is specifically responsible for body growth, and its deficiency causes reduced height.

questions.question_text: Why is personal hygiene particularly important during adolescence?

options.text: Because increased activity of sweat and oil glands can cause body odour and skin problems
Because hygiene was not important in childhood

questions.explanation_correct: During adolescence, hormonal changes increase the activity of sweat and oil (sebaceous) glands. This can lead to increased perspiration, body odour, and acne. Regular bathing and personal hygiene help manage these changes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hygiene is always important, not just during adolescence. The specific reason it becomes more critical during this period is the increased activity of sweat and oil glands due to hormonal changes, which can cause skin issues.

questions.question_text: Endocrine glands are also called ductless glands because:

options.text: They pour their hormones directly into the bloodstream without any ducts
They do not produce any secretions

questions.explanation_correct: Endocrine glands are called ductless glands because they do not have any ducts or tubes. Instead, they secrete their hormones directly into the bloodstream, which carries them to target organs throughout the body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Endocrine glands are not ductless because of small or blocked ducts — they simply do not have ducts at all. They produce secretions (hormones) and release them directly into the blood for transport.

questions.question_text: Teenagers are sometimes called adolescents. At what age does the adolescent period typically end?
questions.explanation_correct: The adolescent period typically ends around 18-19 years of age. By this time, most individuals have reached their full height, and the body has completed the major changes associated with puberty.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 13 and 15 are still within adolescence. 25 is well into adulthood. Adolescence spans from about 11 to 18-19 years, with the body reaching reproductive maturity and full physical development by the end.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the most important nutritional requirement during adolescence?

options.text: A balanced diet containing proteins, carbohydrates, fats, vitamins, and minerals

questions.explanation_correct: Adolescents need a balanced diet containing all nutrients: proteins (for growth and repair), carbohydrates (for energy), fats (in moderation), vitamins, and minerals (like iron and calcium). No single nutrient is sufficient alone.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Relying on only one type of nutrient would lead to deficiencies. Adolescence involves rapid growth that requires all types of nutrients working together — proteins for building tissues, carbohydrates for energy, and vitamins/minerals for various body functions.
